title: The 7 Biggest Mistakes Companies Are Making with AI and Agent Adoption

rawLines.text: Hello friends, as you know it's spring
break week and we are doing a series of
interviews with really interesting
guests and today we are joined once
again by Newfar Gaspar. Newfar has led
AI efforts at Intel. She consults with
numerous companies of all sizes
including some of the biggest in the
world on their AI adoption strategy and
she works with me at Super Intelligent
on our agent readiness audits. In this
episode, we're going to explore some
common mistakes that we're seeing when
it comes to AI and agent adoption with
some recommendations for how to avoid
them.
All right, Newfar, welcome back to the
AI Daily Brief. How's it going? Good.
Great to be here. Yeah. So, so we have a
we have a lot more to talk about because
we've we've had a chance to do a lot
more stuff since last you were here. Um,
we've been uh we've been doing these
agent readiness audits in the super
context where we're learning directly
from companies, you know, what what
they're doing with AI and agents, what
their challenges are, what's working
well, what's working, what's not. You've
also been working independently of that
with with a number of companies. So we
have we have sort of a a big big
interesting base of material I think to
to pull from today. Right. And we've
been seeing companies of all sizes,
right? From like a handful of people all
the way to the biggest companies out
there. Yeah. And I think that that's one
of the things that we'll talk about and
it will be interesting to to sort of
keep in mind is how different or similar
these challenges are kind of across
across different size of company as well
as across things like industry vertical.
So, so what we wanted to talk about
today is the sort of challenges or
common mistakes that companies are
making. Basically, things that are
holding them back from where they could
be and where they want to be and
potentially some specific real world
strategies to to actually help them. So,
we've got seven of those mistakes. What
we're going to do is we'll go through
them kind of one by one. I'll I'll sort
of set up and have you uh explain a
little bit about it and then we'll we'll
talk through each one. Is there anything
else that we should have in mind though
as background before we dive into to
each of these in terms of just set
setting the stage for for where
companies are broadly speaking? Yeah. So
I think there are two things that also
come across a lot when you do your
weekly um long reads and other more
opinionated stuff is that some people
are starting to get a little bit
frustrated with the the big gap between
what the media like yourself is
promising that we should be able to do
with AI. Uh we as in in companies versus
what actually happens on the ground. So
there is like a a very big uh gap there.
And while what we're going to discuss
here is not based on any very detailed
survey of of thousands of participants,
it's very fresh and anecdotally comes
from many different people and sources.
So that's why I feel very comfortable
with what we're sharing. From what I'm
seeing recently, I'm seeing different
responses of leaders and managers to the
current gap between AI promise and
deliverable basically. Uh so some of the
managers are starting to get a little
bit more perhaps I don't know if skeptic
is the right word but a little bit more
careful with uh how they're willing to
invest in AI even in one of the largest
companies out there. I'm hearing that
they're not willing to introduce new
tools as easily as they used to do like
one or two years ago and they're much
more worried about the ROI and and any
guarantees about the new tools and
agents and AI whatever that will be
introduced. So that's one uh like a
persona of behavior that that we're
seeing. The other are people that are
still very excited, but they're
expecting agents to be like the silver
bullets and in some cases even do like a
a leaprog uh beyond having basically
nothing now and expecting agents to help
them bridge the gap. In some cases, it
might help them bridge the gaps. and
others. Uh we all know that agents are
not silver bullets and we will discuss
some strategies and things that they can
do in order to get much more from agents
and in general uh we're still seeing
mistakes across the board and and we
believe that there is so much more that
we can do um from what is being done now
in order to really get the value and not
stay in this uh frustrated period of of
promise versus deliverable. Yeah. One
thing that I'm noticing as well that I
think is putting sort of or is about to
put even more pressure on this is there
has been obviously a big increase in
general global market volatility and
instability over the last few weeks and
already I'm seeing it translate to new
urgency and pressure around can AI and
agents specifically actually deliver and
more pressure to to try to figure that
out, right? The more tense companies are
about cost, the more that they are
hoping that these things can be sort of
great saviors and the challenges take on
even a bigger urgency. You know, it's AI
has never really been a field where
people could take 3 or 6 months off and
just see how it develops. Um, but I
think that that's even less so now. And
so even even as perhaps some of that
skepticism or frustration is increasing,
I don't see leadership taking their
their foot off the gas pedal at all. So,
you know, it's it's an interesting time.
But let's dive into to some of these
common mistakes and see see how much we
can uh kind of help people move through
them. So the first that that you shared
is this idea of a single direction
approach to how agent and AI innovation
should happen. Um so what do you mean by
single direction? So I I've seen two
things. One is organizations kind of
expecting that AI will only happen in a
very organic way kind of a grassroot.
Their internal employees will be psyched
about AI. They will bring ideas. Perhaps
they will work about their innovation in
the nighttime and in the daytime will
continue to do the regular job and
through that approach everything will
happen and and all the promise will be
fulfilled. And from what we've seen it's
not really the case like even if those
grassroot and and these employees are
very very talented bringing great ideas.
The best that they get by doing that as
a side gig is to have a very good demo
or a very good pilot. But then comes the
time that you have to productize and
then they say but that's not my role to
support whatever AI capability that I
will create this incredible rag system
will require some maintenance someone
will need to like open a a support
ticket and and uh close them and so on
and they're saying that's not my job so
um maybe someone else will take it to
production and then uh we're seeing many
uh very great initiatives kind of hold
in that phase and in in other cases
employees don't even do much beyond
perhaps using the tools for their
day-to-day job because they're just too
busy to get themselves less busy. H they
just don't have the the bandwidths
allocation from their managers. So
that's one direction where it only will
get you thus far. In in the other
direction, we're sometimes seeing
organizations where the managers are so
psyched that they're kind of taking a
top down approach to AI adoption. H as
an example, one CEO was saying, "Hey,
we're going to be an AI first company
and we're going to do everything with AI
and we're going to only hire agents from
now on and so on." And then you
interview as part of our audits um the
employees and you realize that there is
a very clear undercurrent of fear of job
loss that there is a an undercurrent of
like a distrust in AI. So it's very
clear when you read those two responses
that that's not going to yield a good
enough result. And even in cases where
managers are are more invested creating
plans and ideation and stuff like that
if they're not working in tandem with
the employees, it it just won't hold
because it's top down and often they
overlook some of what really bothers
employees, how they're actually using,
what are the day-to-day challenges and
they're only seeing from a very uh like
bird's eye view. everything looks very
clear and and that's not necessarily the
case once you go into the details of the
agent uh implementation and the use
cases themselves. Yeah, it's
interesting. I mean it sounds like even
though we're talking about there being
sort of this this challenge from two
directions like people are either
missing sort of the the support for
bottoms up or they're missing the need
for bottoms up you know involvement with
top down decision-m. They're both
fundamentally questions of leadership
right leadership deficits just in in
very different ways. either leadership
that hasn't sort of helped people figure
out how to take their experiments and
and turn them into something broader and
connected them with sort of the
resources to design a full system around

got buy in. I mean is is that a fair
kind of characterization? Um the second
one perhaps I will like caveat a little
bit that often they do have the buy in
but they they believe that they know
enough to make the decision for the
organization and then they're not the
ones that going to go and execute and
the one that going to go and use so
they're missing critical details and
thereby it will not uh succeed. Yeah, I
think that this is this is definitely
something that is emergent from these
audits because we do these audits both
on sort of a a leadership level where
it's you know a handful of of leaders
across the organization but we also
often get down to the individual
contributor or employee level as well.
And a common thing is managers even who
were individual contributors themselves
a few years ago there is a certain
atrophy of what the day-to-day actual
job looks like how processes have
changed right we live in a very very
dynamic work environment where even
outside of AI the way that you get
things done the context in which you do
things is evolving so quickly that there
can be you know a meaningful gap between
managers understanding of how work
happens and uh and employees who are
doing the works understanding of how
work happens which when you're trying to
make decisions around you know work
augmentation or task replacement that
those can be pretty critical differences
in in perspective. Yeah. Yeah. I agree.
And and when you look from from a very
very bird's eye view I always laugh like
like it's when you fly high enough all
the lines seem straight and if you if
you are too senior that always happens
to you and it's it's not their fault.
it's just the the granularity in which
they can operate. So I again the risk of
being reductive every time because I
think it's you know it's it's very
challenging to paint with a broad brush
the prescription but it does feel like
there are there are a couple common sort
of ways to to counteract this or or
perhaps maybe even an even better way to
look at it is organizations who aren't
struggling with this particular
challenge like what is it what is it
that they're doing that makes them sort
of not not succumb to this particular
set of issues? Yeah. So it it will
probably not surprise you and the
audience that we're talking about the
two uh direction approach to kind of
merge the top down and the bottom up
because we have to have the leadership
like you said it is a leadership
challenge first and foremost but we also
have to have the um experts and the the
employees that will be the uh super
users and users of the system in the

you will probably say in some uh case

when it comes the time to allocate the

to pay for a vendor, they understand the

as much time as as people are are
quoting. So it needs to be a kind of a
birectional thing. And even if it's a
grassroot, I think it's very important
for leaders to say, okay, this is a
direction that we're encouraging
innovation versus this is something that
was already handled elsewhere or not a
strategic direction that we want to go
uh to. So perhaps not to stifle
innovation because that's not what we
want to do, but also not to uh make it
so open-ended that people are basically
wasting companies uh resources because
they have an idea and it's not going to
go um anywhere. Yeah, I I think that um
it's you know it's worth noting too. I
see agents as exacerbating rather than
helping this problem. I think that
agents are inherently more replacing
than augmenting at least in terms of how
people think about them currently. You
know, agent the ROI that companies are
looking for from agents is can they do a

what that doesn't say is how companies

slash headcount or are they going to

is is going to be absolutely integral to

employee concern. I I I basically I
think that agents are ratcheting up the

right than than it is currently. Maybe
let's move to number two. Characterized

number one, but but speak more to what
what the the common mistake here is. So
here often it's it's a yeah, it's a
little bit of a continuation, but often
what you will see is like a a best

when we interviewed companies that are

a huge uh difference in in what they

that's not something that will get you
to good results. Another funny anecdote

talking about one uh title is very
little governance uh very little uh
policy uh in many cases not articulated
like you said before even if in some

the adoption even something as simple as

create huge difference versus companies

whatever out there. So yeah, so let's
let's go into the prescription a little

for how to get this right from what
we're seeing right now? Because
obviously you got to imagine that this
is fairly evolutionary and the best way

different from different organizations
but what are common best practices that
we're that we're starting to see? Um, so
one thing that I'm seeing repeatedly and
I don't know if it's a popular opinion,
but in what we're seeing is that in

more than 10% weekly which what many

their employees and that's not enough
but some kind of a dedicated uh group
and a council that oversees AI adoption
across the company. It can be cross

dotted to the CTO chief AI officer or or
chief information officer. It doesn't
matter as long as there is a very clear
team that is uh the owner of AI.
Typically, this is where you see much
more mature results, better results. So
that's one thing that is uh very
important. The other is having a clear
AI policy and it should be proportional

they have the information security
officers and every everyone on board to

what is the company policy and they
should and can revise it over time but
at least have something that the

it's super interesting. My my sense too

there's a natural centralization there
also when you're first exploring getting

Counterintuitively, it sort of increases

And so that that you know that the
